text: It's been almost 100 years
since physicists Erwin Schrodinger
and Werner Heisenberg blew apart

our understanding
of the Universe.

Instead of a world
ruled by certainty,

where everything was definite
and precise,

the theory they developed
described a world
that was fuzzy and uncertain.

They asserted
that at the microscopic level,
atoms behave in unpredictable ways.

Particles can exist
in several places at once
and pass through energy barriers

like ghosts drifting
through solid walls.
Welcome to quantum mechanics.

Although initially seen
as strange and puzzling,

quantum mechanics
is now universally accepted

as giving us the best description
of the microscopic world,

and embracing its fuzziness has led
us to a much better understanding

of the building blocks
of the Universe.

Without this understanding,
we would never have developed

the silicon chip,
the laser or the smartphone.

The development of quantum
technology now has the potential

to transform our lives
to an even greater extent.

To understand how,
we need to look at

two of the more counterintuitive -
some might say even bonkers - ideas

about the behaviour
of the quantum world -
superposition and entanglement.
Superposition describes the ability

of particles
like electrons, photons or atoms
to be in two locations at once

or move in two different directions
at the same time.

At our everyday scale, objects exist
in one definite state at a time.

However, in the microscopic
quantum world,

we can't know the state
of a particle until we observe it,

forcing our everyday certainty
on it

and causing its quantum state
to "collapse"
into just one definite state.
Confused?

Well, take a look
at a thought experiment
devised by our friend Schrodinger.

Schrodinger asked what would happen
if a cat were shut in a box

with a radioactive substance
that would kill it
if it released a particle.

But quantum mechanics tells us
that we must describe the particle

as having been both released
and not released at the same time.

It exists
in a quantum superposition.

Since the state of the cat
now rests on this quantum event

that has both happened
and not happened,

it too must be both dead
and alive simultaneously.

We only force it to "choose"
when we open the box to look.

The weird thing is that
we know this is true of atoms,

but it never happens
for actual cats,
even though cats are made of atoms.
The second mind-blowing behaviour

observed in this microscopic world
is quantum entanglement.

This is where two or more particles
are linked

in a way that everyday physics
cannot explain.

For example, if two separated
particles, A and B, are entangled,
then each will be in a superposition

of spinning both clockwise
and anticlockwise at the same time.

If an observation of A
then forces it into one state -
say, spinning clockwise -

then particle B will be found to be
spinning in the opposite direction.

Its superposition will collapse
when we measure A.

In principle, this works even
if one of the particles is on Mars
and the other is on Earth.
This phenomenon is so bizarre,

Einstein famously rejected
the idea of it,

describing it as
"spooky action at a distance".

That's the point
of quantum technology.

It's to make large things,
like the processor of a computer,
behave like a tiny quantum object.

The strange and wonderful concepts
of entanglement and superposition

are crucial in the development
of new quantum technologies.

Quantum computers solve complex
problems at a massively faster rate

than our most powerful
conventional ones.

Rather than using
the classical binary system
of bits, zeros and ones,

quantum computers use qubits -
quantum bits
that can exist in a superposition

of both zero and one states
simultaneously.

Quantum computers can readily
find the most efficient route
through multiple destinations

or analyse highly complex
financial markets.

Scientists believe
the power of quantum computing
could revolutionise many industries,
help us tackle climate change

and even discover
new drug treatments.
Alongside quantum computing,

there's the possibility
of developing quantum sensing.

These are incredibly delicate
optical or magnetic sensors

that can be used
for a whole range of applications -

from earlier warnings of earthquakes
or volcanic eruptions
to next-generation brain imaging

that could provide ground-breaking
insights for battling dementia.

Then we have quantum communication -
or encryption -

which will revolutionise
IT security.
Right now, when paying online,

we know that current encryption
methods make our details
relatively secure.

But as soon as quantum computers
are developed,

they'll be able to easily
break through the current systems.

Luckily, we're also developing
what's called quantum encryption,

which uses the concepts
of superposition and entanglement.

This will mean that when
two parties exchange messages,
they can be secure in the knowledge

that if anyone tries to "eavesdrop"
on the information,
the superposition will collapse,

affecting the exchanges and alerting
them to any potential interception.

Quantum computing, quantum sensing
and quantum encryption -

the quantum revolution
has already begun.

We may not know if Schrodinger's cat
is alive or dead, or both,

but harnessing the wonderful,
mysterious properties

of the quantum world looks set
to turbo-charge our futures.
